job_title: Learning & Development Partner in London, England
pros: Working at Peabody feels meaningful and purposeful, because you are contributing to making the lives of vulnerable people easier. The colleagues I worked with are so smart, passionate and hard working. I enjoyed my time working with my team, particularly going through a really challenging time during the pandemic.
cons: During my time I experienced a large number of team members making the decision to leave and ultimately I did too, because we struggled with a lack of effective leadership. No changes were made despite concerns being widely and formally confirmed

job_title: Data and Information Manager in London, England
pros: 30 days leave, 35 hour week
cons: Merger crazy with no regard for its impact upon employees

pros: we had some nice sites. good locations.
cons:
i've never worked anywhere so disorgansied. we were expected to deal with sometime 3 or 4 sites and the sales progression, handovers, attend meetings and be in the office when the managers told us.

The workload was too much. unfortunately it was obvious from the day i started that the leadership team have no experience in anything other than housing. it was so backward. we were told to handover property to buyers when it was not ready just to get the numbers in. 

Some times we had to wait over a month for a sales manager to approve a deal and then they decided "no, we're going to rent that one out". It was so embarrasing. if you aren't selling enough, they just give the site to an estate agent so it takes the heat off them. they think they're being clever.
i tried to talk to directors but she didn't want to know. she never answers calls or emails and just passes the buck all the time. 

the final straw for me was the merger with catalyst. we were all hoping we would get the director from catalyst because we knew that he knew his stuff and was well respected, but no, we unfortunately kept the one who doesn't know her stuff. I reckon she was cheaper, everything is on the cheap here now. Now its all gone to the dogs and i dont want to hang around in this shambles.

pros: People I met whilst working there. Location.
cons: Did not feel respected or appreciated. Not listened to. Decisions are made by SMT however did not consult on how these decisions would impact the people who do the role every day

pros: epic cool super very nice
cons: very good not even that bad

review_title: Total Shambles run by the "Lets do lunch" brigade
pros: Nice office refurb now complete
cons:
The place has gone to the dogs. We have a new "Executive team" who don't appear to know their backside from their elbow, none of them seem to have any credible experience apart from being former croanies of our new esteemed CEO. Jobs have been handed out to the boys and anyone who's friends with them of course. Nice touch.

Sadly, our leader has had what may be considered a promotion and taken it upon themselves to create even more layers around them to allow her more time to go out to lunch with suppliers. Although this was apparently against policy, it doesn't seem matter. 

The entire department is a total mess, no structure, no one knows what they're doing and our Direcotor is no where to be seen.... well correction... try the local pub having a long boozy lunch with some estate agent mates!

We spend good money after bad on ridiculous campaigns and we're supposed to be a charity. No one questions this.

We get poor sales results and no one cares, no one checks and no one holds anyone to account. 

Unfortunately, I can no longer work in an environment where people have either given up, checked out or gone for a long boozy lunch!

pros: Nice colleagues Good initiatives nice office
cons: Career progression employee engagment from managemtn

cons: Pay, structure, complaints, work load, deadlines

review_title: A great place to work and make a significant difference in people's life.
pros: Great people, great working environment and above all, Peabody gives me the opportunity to make a good impact in people's life.
cons: Working with vulnerable people, especially people with mental health can be challenging sometimes.

review_title: People at the top are not Human or Kind
pros: The people on the front line is what makes Peabody great, everyone is supportive of each other. I had a great Manager but they got rid of her too.
cons: No logic at the top and never held accountable when things go wrong, CEO and his people are in their own world and don't know what they are doing. In the heart of Covid this bunch of people decided to get rid of the whole employment team,because one idiotic, useless woman thought that it was wise...what a mess and I bet she still there. People up there need to be held accountable for thei actions... dodgy contractors brought in and signed off by CEO. Yeah no need to say how much they really care about people. Let's not mention the crap quality of properties they are scamming people to buy so much so Panorama made a documentary on it.

review_title: Restrictive + Stressful at Pitsea Call Centre
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Pitsea, England
pros: - 30 day holiday entitlement excluding public holidays
cons:
- You could have 30 days holiday, but you weren't always entitled to the day off you would want as all holidays are given away first-come, first-serve. You could end up not having a day off for months 

- Toxic work culture with no racial or cultural diversity 

- Highly time-pressured environment and you could not even go to the bathroom without being questioned why you "took so long". It was degrading, especially as a woman, being questioned by a man about the length of time I've spent in the toilet. (I was on my period) 

- No pathway to upskilling and moving up the career ladder

- Stressful targets amidst the lack of support from senior staff. Would be threatened with job security 

- Favouritism and nepotism is rife with parking space allowance, and holiday choice for specific workers

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Royal Tunbridge Wells, England
pros: You get Good job satisfaction.
cons:
Terrible HR department, who bully and harass when you have time off sick.
The atmosphere can be like a playground, cliques and bullies.

review_title: Was a great place to work but sadly going downhill
pros: Its the people working on the front line that are amazing. The organisation is made up of hardworking, friendly and approachable staff.
cons: Doesn't live up to all the talk about investing in its people. In recent years its become very clique. Too much talking about the future and little in the way of delivery. Management let the side down.

review_title: A good place to work if your face fits
job_title: Part of the Corporate Services Team in London, England
pros: Most of the staff are helpful and do care about residents
cons: Peabody has grown exponentially and it has become a bureaucratic giant. A lot of nepotism now takes place - if your face fits you'll go far regardless of how competent you are. This means that a lot of people are promoted beyond their capabilities while others fall by the wayside. Also some teams are very 'cliquey' and the genuine people often don't get a look in. It never used to be like this - so depressing.

job_title: Associate Business Analyst in London, England
pros: - salary in line with market rate
cons:
- Leadership team not approachable
- No real evidence of any 'leading' from the 'leadership' team
- Lack of trust among staff/departments
- Reluctant to change to adopt modern ways of working

review_title: Avoid - poor salary, poor culture, poor prospects
pros:
- Lambeth head office is easy to get to
- There are 2 exits from this office
- Coffee in the canteen is decent and cheap (although this is an external company providing)
-  Free wifi in the office
- Office work tends to be 9 - 5, so can at least have some life outside of work (but this is common in most places so hardly a pro)
cons:
- A culture of 'brown-nosing' is prevalent in many departments. Leading to managers, directors, etc., whose only ability is to suck up to more senior people and send unnecessary emails, call unnecessary meetings
- Culture of micromanagement, people watching, and the like
- Salary is massively below market rate for similar roles in similar companies, worse still than similar roles in different sectors
- Benefits are not good at all
- Lots of HR-speak and bureaucracy that is not needed
- Archaic IT systems and ways of doing things
-  Lots of talk but no action on feedback to company
- Offices are in dire need of redecorating and deep cleaning
- Prospects are non-existent

review_title: Your experience will depend greatly on your department and its culture
pros:
Very helpful well meaning colleaugesat the operational staff level.
The Office closes over the christmas holidays (3 extra days holiday)
Team away days 
In-house canteen 
Bike surgery days 
Extra days leave to carry out charitable works for the local community (known as Peabody Promise)
Professional development and support 
Massively subsidenced Royal Albert Hall Tickets
cons:
Clicky sub-groups within department which perpetuates a high school primitive culture
No flexible working
You're likely to experience your self-motivation diminish very quickly if you don't become initiated into the gang/click attributes and behaviours of sub-group/s (ridiculious)
Lack of transparency and dissemination of meaningful information

pros: Great perks, generous holiday allowance, a week off at Christmas for almost all employees on top of that, Bupa once you have been there enough years, excellent pension terms, Royal Albert Hall tickets (via an inexpensive raffle). They will be there for you as well if the worst happens and you need to take an extended period of absence. An ambitious company that tries to go above what others in the sector would attempt.
cons: A lack of maturity across all departments means day to day experience of work can be frustrating. An obvious quality that is lacking is discipline. Things have been getting better with the introduction of a company business plan that informs departmental strategy but it still very often seems like that gets lost by teams working on day to day activities.

review_title: People Make You Want to Work For The Company
pros:
A Social company with out of office activities after work organised by employees
Some great benefits which fit well into their Social Care of residence and employees.
People will Thank you for helping them and actually mean it.
People work hard to achieve goals because they are passionate about the company.
cons:
Large Area to in London for certain roles. Would normally have expected free TFL pass to cover from NW to SE London
Terrible salary not in line for Central London.
This is a Not for Profit organisation rather than a charity.
Clicky
Don't stick to promises.
Interim Managment
Currently a Time of Change so Tense Atmosphere

review_title: Some good benefits but poor systems
pros:
Pay and benefits
Overall friendly environment
Care for staff
cons:
The infrastructure particularly IT is very poor. 
There can also be a blame culture between departments which gets in the way of progress. 
The executive on the whole don't listen to what is going on at the front line.
